Like the rest of the country, we buy most of our things from China. There are a million ways of being weird, of being not normal, but Portland has plenty of normal. Portland has yoga and hipsters and business professionals. Perhaps weird means we just take all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers and herbs and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summertime. Free boxes are traditionally cardboard boxes containing items someone is getting rid of, but they can be plastic bags or boxes. They contain something magical, a treasure just perfect for the person wandering by, a surprising amount of the time. Free boxes tend to have clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. That is, what Portland is all about to me, but I am just one variety of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real live goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people who pursue our dreams, or dream about pursuing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug problems tend to be (at their root) mental health problems, and the constant rain through much of the year, plus the dreary clouds, appear to be a contributor. Portland has a homelessness problem too, which no one seems to know what to do with. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than in most parts of the country, but our services are insufficient, as in all parts of the country. The non-homeless population wavers between care and hatred. In this, we are not weird at all.
The mountains are always there. In the north, bearing witness to the sun’s journey every dawn and every dusk. No matter how much I forget about them or how caught up with work and life I am to notice, they are there, unwavering, unopposed, and unphased by life’s tribulations. Then on days when I am the most stressed and wound, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them they let me rest my anxious soul, lending me some strength to go on, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergrad, and the mountains to the north of campus where what first captivated me. Sure, the university has its own share of breathtaking sights in buildings and ponds and trees, which have their own share of my heart, but it’s the mountains that really holds its throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own right. There are countless cafés that were home to many hours of caffeine fueled cramming. One can walk or take the bus just a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded colored bricks that line restaurants and office buildings. It is here that this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as it’s neighboring urban city. This doesn’t last for many blocks though, as one can escape, once again, to the serene small town by passing the library. This dichotomy of atmospheres in such proximity truly give this city a wonderous vibe as if it was beckoning to be explored. With this, it is easy to create many a cherished memory, each in association with a certain part of town. Whether it is walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch the movie in the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places are bound to be in life. The ponds, in particular, can be a rather fitting place for reflection as well as crying sessions at two in the morning in the middle of an existential crisis. The latter of which, I have more experience in. While watching the turtles and ducks and insects live out their lives, each with some contribution or role, I couldn’t help but wonder about my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, and past the park and little houses that scream of suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that sun shined its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they had always been. The sturdy overbearing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building in the horizon, and as if speaking without words, stirred in me my sense of perseverance.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts: In these vast, sprawling streets where commerce and habitation intertwine, I find myself amidst a labyrinth of contrasts. Commercial districts, like a cancerous growth, metastasize into residential areas, where diverse enterprises and establishments thrive. From the towering monoliths of corporate offices to the intimate, quaint boutiques that line the thoroughfares, there's no shortage of sustenance or solace. A stroll through the streets reveals a tapestry of cultures, from the vibrant hues of Little Armenia to the quiet whispers of the Orthodox Jewish enclave. Yet, amidst this cacophony of diversity, the city's pulse quickens and slows at the whim of the clock. The parks, oases of tranquility, are frequented by the younger set, a stark contrast to the elderly who needle through the city's veins, their faces etched with the sag of years. The city, a beast of asphalt and steel, groans under the weight of its own expansion. New apartments, like tumors, sprout from the earth, their shadows darkening the sun-kissed neighborhoods. The city breathes, exhales, and the traffic, a serpentine nightmare, chokes its lifeblood. The houses, a tapestry of designs and dreams, stand sentinel amidst the chaos. They bear witness to the city's history, as the people who inhabit them ebb and flow, their lives a dance with the city's heartbeat. Yet, these faces are ever-changing, a revolving door of strangers, their stories woven into the city's fabric, yet forever elusive.

In the heart of these unassuming streets, a forgotten world persists. A world where the suburban dream of yore lingers, albeit faded and worn, like the paint on these weathered clapboard houses. Some homes have been cleaved asunder, yet remain tethered, their shared walls echoing the dreams they once harbored. The yards, once verdant and meticulously tended, now bear the scars of time, and the driveways, though still hosting a car or two, seem to echo the diminishing optimism of their owners. This neighborhood, a relic of a bygone era, clings to the remnants of its glory, its public school standing sentinel, a beacon of hope for the youth and a nostalgic mirror for the elders.

The church spires, once a beacon of unity, now stand mostly empty, yet the basketball courts echo with the laughter of youth, unbridled and free. The supermarket, a bastion for the Yemni family, stands as a testament to the melting pot that is this neighborhood, where the vast majority hail from the African American community. Football is the language of these streets, their wide expanses echoing with the cries of young voices as they chase the ball, pausing only to yield to the rumbling of passing cars.

The movie theater, a relic from a time when cinema was a communal experience, now screens old films at a discount, its audience a mix of the old and the young, the latter often favoring the familiarity of the old over the novelty of the new. The karate school, a once aspiring haven for would-be karate kids, now houses a pharmacy, a stark reminder of the fleeting nature of trends and the enduring allure of the familiar.

A single expressway bisects our town, its entrance and exit located in the neighboring town. A petition, once championed by the youth, advocated for an entrance here, yet the elders, citing the potential ruination of their sanctuary, thwarted its passage. A new high school is being built, and with it, the question of a mascot, a symbol of our town's identity. I propose a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin, a representation of the blending of the old and the new, the familiar and the futuristic, much like our neighborhood itself.

In the shadow of the dilapidated Whole Foods, behind the annual inhabitants of the hotels, there lies a forgotten town, a hidden community that has been left to the relics of time and the remnants of a once-thriving era. The first glance might reveal nothing but decrepitude, yet if one were to venture further, past the crumbling walls and the faded dreams of the past, one might stumble upon a world that few dare to enter. Here, apartments stand like weathered sentinels, their once-proud facades now scarred by the ravages of time and the whispered secrets of their inhabitants. They are not the sort of dwellings one would expect to find in such a place, yet they exist, stacked upon one another like the layers of a decaying cake, each one bearing its own tales of heartache and triumph.

The first apartments, the ones that have danced with infamy in the cold light of the news, are best left to the shadows, for appearances can be as deceptive as the truth. But as you press on, you'll find a different world, a world that thrives in the silence and the forgotten corners of this forsaken land. The complexes stand like silent observers, their walls whispering tales of lives lived and dreams lost. Across from them stands the community college's satellite campus, a quiet oasis amidst the chaos, where the students shuffle in with coffee in hand, their faces a mask of tired resignation. The gates creak open, admitting them one by one, as the commuters, trapped in their metal cages, groan and fume at the delay.

The road, a twisted serpent, opens onto another residential street, where a park lies alongside a rehabilitation center, its cheerful porch furniture and lazy ceiling fan a stark contrast to the grim reality of the world outside. Here, children play, their laughter echoing through the air like a balm to the weary heart, while retired folk walk their dogs, their scowls a testament to the changing times. The strip mall beside the park stands as a testament to the modern age, its stores a beacon of hope amidst the decay. The sushi place, the swimming supply store, and the nail salon all stand side by side, a symphony of contradictions, each one a slice of life in this forgotten town. The frozen yogurt place, with its DIY toppings and the teens who cluster around it, is a sight to behold, their laughter a stark contrast to the silent streets that surround them.

This neighborhood, a slice of Americana, a piece of history in the sleepy south, is a testament to the resilience of the human spirit. Here, time seems to stand still, as if frozen in the amber of memory. It is a world that few dare to enter, yet those who do find a sense of belonging, a sense of purpose in the silence and the forgotten corners of this untamed land.

She inquired, "Where are we?" as we traversed the sprawling expanse of cornfields that stretched out before us, a sea of gold as far as the eye could see. I replied, "This is it," knowing that the stark emptiness would startle her, for she was a creature of the city, where the grocery store was but a short walk from her doorstep. She was from a place where the horizon was a constant hum of concrete and steel, not this vast, untamed wilderness. The cornfields, they were a strange sight, a testament to the silent toil of the farmer, the endless dance of the winds, and the earth's unyielding patience. I shared with her tales of my youth in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she saw me, saw who I was and where I came from.

To the west, a quarry lay, its waters still and deep, like the eye of some ancient beast. Beyond it, we found my dwelling, a stone's throw from the earth, nestled amongst a patchwork of brick and stucco homes, each claiming a half-acre of land as their own. The drivers of these homes were Mercedes, their gleaming hides a testament to hard work and the pursuit of the finer things. They gleamed in the sun, freshly washed, like the gleam of a well-oiled gun barrel.

My Korean neighbor was ever present, his eyes bright and his smile wide. He was a man of the land, his hands calloused and his laughter infectious. In his youth, he had been a healer, a man of knowledge and skill. Now, he tended to his lawn, his hum a melody of the modern world, a symphony of progress and the simple pleasures of living. His laughter was like music, a song sung to the wind, and we all knew it, knew the joy it brought to our souls.

My home was a modest affair, a grey stucco house with a side yard teeming with geese, their honks a symphony of the wild. Our terrier chased them, his barks echoing against the house, a primal song of the hunt. In the backyard, a stream babbled, its waters clear and cool, a living thing that sang to the bullfrogs and the distant cows. Over a wooden bridge, untouched by time, lay an oasis, a testament to nature's resilience, her wildness untamed. It was here, in this sanctuary, that I spent my youth, building forts and chasing dreams, the laughter of childhood echoing through the trees.

Winters in our small town were brutal, a harsh beauty that left the earth bare and the trees stark. The snow fell, a soft whisper of silence, the world holding its breath. The backyard, it transformed, a winter wonderland, a frozen kingdom. My sister and I, we fought, our battles waged not with steel but with snowballs. We built forts, castles of ice and snow, weapons of war, our laughter echoing through the cold. It was our kingdom, our wonderland, a place where the cares of the world faded away, and we were just kids, free and wild.

Portland, Oregon, a city of stark contrasts and peculiarities, bears the unofficial motto, "Keep Portland Weird," scrawled in a nook of a joint that serves as a pizza parlor, bar, music hall, and a shadowy sanctuary for those who dance on the edge of the law. To some, it is a mournful elegy for the Portland of yesteryears, a time when the city was less known and less costly, fostering a peculiar, underground culture. To others, it is a siren call, beckoning to those who embrace the absurd, to those who would rather be called strange than ordinary. Yet, amidst the torrent of affluent Californians and the ceaseless construction of condominiums, Portland remains an enigma, an enigma that is not always welcoming, but certainly accepting of the extraordinary.

The weirdness of Portland is not a monochromatic affair, but a kaleidoscope of the mundane and the bizarre. We buy our trinkets from the distant shores of China, and we have our share of modern strife. Yet, Portland is not just a repository of quirkiness; it is also a city of yoga practitioners, hipsters, and businessmen. Perhaps, in this strange amalgamation, lies the essence of Portland's weirdness - a peculiar irreverence towards the ordinary.

My neighborhood, much like others in Portland, is a symphony of color, with homes adorned with flowers, herbs, and vegetables lining the streets. In the summer, free boxes materialize, containing treasures left for the taking. These are not just cardboard boxes, but portals to the unexpected. Here, you might find clothes, books, or even the occasional dream. The magical potential of a neighborhood stroll is what Portland is all about, at least to me, but I am but one variant of the city's myriad peculiarities.

Portland is a city of passionate pursuits and passions pursued, where one might find a game of goat yoga or a soccer match, but it is also a city haunted by a drug problem, a problem that is often a symptom of a deeper, more insidious disease. The rain and the clouds, it is said, contribute to this affliction, but the true cause is harder to pinpoint. Homelessness, too, is a blight that Portland shares with many other cities. Our social services, while better than most, are insufficient, and the city's inhabitants sway between compassion and contempt.

In this, Portland is not unique. In this, Portland is not weird. Yet, in the peculiar, the strange, the unexpected, Portland finds its true character.

The peaks stand sentinel, unyielding, their silent vigil unbroken by the ceaseless dance of day and night. They are the steadfast witnesses to the sun's labored ascent and descent, unfazed by the trivialities of mortal existence that come and go like the tides. Even when I'm lost in the labyrinthine dance of academia or enmeshed in the mundane, they remain, a constant in the ever-changing tableau of life. On days when the weight of the world presses down upon me with all its cruel might, they beckon, offering respite from the tumult. Their ancient, unchanging faces seem to whisper words of encouragement, urging me to press onward, one halting step at a time.

I first beheld these titans of stone when I arrived to commence my education here. Their grandeur drew me in, a siren's call to the unwary. The campus, with its own share of architectural marvels and natural wonders, held me in its thrall, but it was the mountains that truly captured my heart. The town, too, has its charms—cafés where countless hours were spent in caffeine-fueled contemplation, and the downtown area, a vibrant tapestry of faded brick and history, where the rhythm of modern life meets the slow, steady pulse of the past. It is a place of contrasts, a wonderland of contradiction, where one can lose oneself in the bustle of the city and yet, in an instant, find refuge in the tranquility of the suburbs.

The ponds, too, hold their secrets. They are the tears of the earth, reflecting the sky's ever-changing moods. I have laid too many of my own tears upon their surface, in moments of despair and doubt. Yet, in their silent, eternal vigil, they offer solace. As I wandered past them, past the park and the houses that whispered of quiet domesticity, I found myself on a main street. The sun painted the sky with strokes of gold and blue, and as I looked up, I saw that I was walking towards the mountains. They stood sentinel, unyielding, their peaks touching the heavens, and in their ancient, immutable silence, they whispered of endurance.

Should you find yourself in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, you'll not be hard-pressed to discover its whereabouts. Public transit is as abundant as a New York City rainstorm, and the neighborhood's urbanity will remind you that you're still in the city's heart. Expect to be greeted by a symphony of Asian-owned stores, a result of two decades' worth of immigration. These establishments are a sight to behold, a stark reminder that Bensonhurst is not merely a melting pot, but a collage of cultures. Supermarkets and laundromats, in particular, are ubiquitous, their popularity owing to the quality of the goods and the pocket-friendly prices. Within a stone's throw, you'll find four such supermarkets, a convenience not to be underestimated. Yet, do not imagine Bensonhurst to be a solely Asian enclave. It is a tapestry of immigrants, their first and second-generation children, and the local born. Asian-owned businesses dominate the landscape, but a recently renovated park lies nearby, boasting ten basketball courts, soccer and baseball fields, handball courts, swings, a playground for the young, and even a water fountain for summer refreshment. Diversity abounds, a testament to New York City's steadfast spirit.

The neighborhood's architecture is a mix of co-op living buildings and condominium apartments, with two-family houses being the norm. The denizens are generally pleasant, though the noise can be a relentless companion. Cars blasting music and tires screeching are commonplace, and the morning alarm is often set by the revving engines. Nighttime heralds caution, for while Bensonhurst is not inherently unsafe, unpredictability is its shadow. Bullying and theft are not unheard of, as I have experienced firsthand in the past. Package theft, too, is a recurring issue. New York's ordinances against dog waste go unheeded, the neighborhood's streets often littered with the unsightly remnants. Keep your shoes clean, for the neighborhood's pet owners are not always diligent.

Where I reside, the paths are few and far between, the landscape falling away in a steep descent, our abode perched atop the highest peak in the neighborhood. 'Workout hill' the locals call it, for the joggers who ascend its slope each day in their daily pursuit of fitness. The road, pitted and worn, offers little respite to the unwary driver. The telephone and electric lines, strung high above, are a tattered tapestry of repair, the constant storms and wind having claimed their toll. The evergreens, dense and tall, are an affront to the view, and so the houses rise, high and proud, their glass fronts gleaming in defiance, each vying for an unobstructed view of the bay. At sunset, the water ignites, the sky ablaze with orange, but it is often clouded, the sun's rays filtered through a grey haze. Most days are damp, the air thick with moisture, moss claiming everything it can: roofs, cars, railings. A month's absence and my automobile had turned verdant, a verdant fur that required hours of labor to remove. Children are scarce, the school a distant echo, yet dogs roam free, their owners' voices a familiar chorus. Rabbits, too, scurry and burrow, their presence a source of consternation for the gardeners, but a source of delight for the cats who prowl. Birds, both small and large, inhabit the skies, their songs a symphony, though the occasional hawk or eagle is chased off by the neighborhood crows. Stores are few and far between, but the waterfront offers a scant few eateries, their fare fresh and unadorned. The beach is but a strip of rocks, the shore's edge a playground for the adventurous. The bay is narrow, the opposite shore visible through the mist on most days.

In the quiet, unassuming reaches of a small southern town in Tennessee, I reside in a house that stands sentinel at the corner of a modest thoroughfare. A parched dusting of concrete threads through the neighborhood, meeting at the junction of two state highways, a fact that lends our street an ever-present hum of life that is not entirely unwelcome. The languid pace of life here is one of familiarity, with the comings and goings of neighbors marked by the steady rhythm of their daily labors. Lawns are tended with a meticulousness that mirrors the seasons themselves, and the scent of pine and woodsmoke permeates the air in the fall, as leaves burn in the fires of neighboring yards.

Our home, a humble abode at the corner of our street, offers a vantage point from which to observe the ebb and flow of our community. The faces we see each day are as familiar as the cars that we come to recognize, and the occasional stranger is noted with a quiet curiosity. The children, their laughter echoing through the streets, are a balm to the senses, and the sight of a neighbor's child cycling by is a picture of simple contentment. The garage, a sanctuary of sorts, serves as my workshop, a place where the rhythm of the day slows and the hum of the neighborhood becomes a comforting lullaby.

Our family, four in number, is as much a part of the neighborhood as the trees that line our streets. The eldest, a young woman of fourteen, and her younger sister, a spirited eleven-year-old, are the lifeblood of our home, their laughter and energy filling the house with a warmth that cannot be measured. We are a family that treasures the simple pleasures of home, the smell of a barbecue on the back deck, the rustle of leaves underfoot, and the subtle comfort of familiarity.

In the quiet moments of the holidays, the neighborhood seems to hold its breath, the air thick with the scent of pine and the promise of togetherness. Thanksgiving, Mother's Day, and Christmas bring with them a sense of anticipation, a shared ritual that binds us together in our shared humanity.

This is our home, a place of quiet beauty and simple pleasures. If it were not for the traffic that rolls through our street, it would be perfect. But as it stands, it is ours, and we are content.

In the grip of the high desert's embrace, my neighborhood lies, a sprawl of earth and rock, where the sun's relentless gaze scorches the land into a perpetually brown stupor. Few can comprehend the monotony of this existence, the endless expanse of dirt and the rare sight of a verdant lawn, a testament to extravagant lawn care. The houses here, once scattered like solitary sentinels, now stand more densely packed, yet still separated by vast expanses, as if a city were burgeoning in the wilderness. The people are generally kind, though the city's dark underbelly lurks, like a shadow in the sun. My neighborhood is an oasis of elderly benevolence, an idyll amidst the encroaching urban sprawl.

The stores here are as ubiquitous as the dust, a procession of chain stores, their neon lights a stark contrast to the desolate landscape. Whole Foods and organic markets remain distant dreams, their scarcity a reflection of the desert's harsh realities. The city's lifeblood is construction, a testament to its ongoing growth. The open spaces, once a source of pride, now fill me with unease, a fear of change etched into the dry soil. I left the city's embrace for this harsh, beautiful land, and I cling to it like a child to a lifeline.

My work is a dance with drywall and T-bar installations, a symphony of screws and gypsum. The desert's wildlife is my solace, a world of lizards and desert bugs, a fascination shared by my children, who roam freely, eyes trained on the ground, seeking their quarry. The desert's stark beauty is a draw, a challenge to those who dare to live within its grasp. To co-exist with its inhabitants, to learn their ways, is a responsibility we shoulder with pride. The desert is a teacher, and we are its students.

In Victorville, the desert's spirit runs deep. The San Bernardino County Fair is a celebration of its unique character, a feast for the senses. Wrightwood's snow-capped peaks beckon, a winter's sanctuary amidst the heat. The Victor Valley Museum whispers tales of the past, of a land carved by time and shaped by the hands of man and beast. It is a place of stark beauty, a testament to the resilience of nature and the indomitable spirit of those who seek to tame it.

When queried about my neighborhood, I reckon my response might strike one as singular. Most who answer thus are likely proprietors of their own abodes, whereas I inhabit a different sort of quarter. My neighborhood is the campus that serves as my home, and the denizens of my dormitory constitute my community. The campus itself, while less intimate, is a part of my neighborhood, albeit of lesser significance.

My neighborhood, peculiar as it is, shares some commonalities with the more ordinary concept. Like any other, it is home to dwellings, inhabitants, shops, and greenspaces. Let us begin with the "houses" that comprise my neighborhood. Before delving into the specifics, it is best to distinguish the types of housing that populate my immediate vicinity. Three types exist: apartments, actual houses, and dormitories. In the apartments, one finds 2-4 souls per room, with 4-6 rooms per floor. The most common buildings accommodate 2 floors, housing approximately 20 individuals apiece. Actual houses, available to those affiliated with the school, are typically 2-4 bedroom setups, often occupied by alumni. They are scarce, however, as they are deemed less efficient. Finally, there are the dormitory rooms, housing hundreds of students. These rooms, with the exception of a rare few, accommodate two individuals. They are the most common type of housing in my neighborhood.

With housing accounted for, we turn our attention to the people. My school boasts diversity, and this is reflected in the makeup of my neighborhood. Among its inhabitants, one finds representatives from various cultures and ages. The professional staff reside in the houses scattered throughout the neighborhood, while the newer students dwell in the dormitories. The older students prefer the apartment-style housing. To speak of the people in this neighborhood is to do them a disservice, so we shall press on to the stores and greenspaces.

Since my school is largely self-contained, it boasts an abundance of shops and a singular park. The stores offer a variety of dining options and the school's unique brand of clothing and grocery stores. In short, anything needed can be found within my neighborhood's boundaries. The park serves as a play area for the diverse inhabitants, kept clean and free from criminal elements by all who call it home.

In this place, I've dwelled for a decade, so I reckon I can share what I know. When I first arrived, it was a godforsaken place, coming from Riverdale to Stockbridge. I wept, goddamn if I didn't, for the love I felt for them all. But my ma and pa, they wanted the best for me and my sister, so here we remained, in this godforsaken neighborhood. It took time, but I made new friends, some who became brothers in arms, and some who turned out to be lesser men. Mr. Glen and his kin, they were different. We shared a quiet kinship, a bond as strong as any family's. I recall the day I caught the white strap from Ms. Veda's leg at their wedding, while the flowers flew unclaimed. We danced the night away, and I danced with Marsharii, their daughter, till the dawn broke.

The neighborhood, it's a labyrinth, but I've learned its ways. I've hung with Kason and Curtis, and we'd while away the days playing games, living life like it was meant to be lived. Sometimes, I'd find solace in the park, where I'd practice my balance, my bokken sword at my side. The courts, they stand empty, but the memories of Mr. Graves' teachings remain. He and my da, they taught us to play, to sweat, to laugh. There's more stories, plenty of them, but these, they're the ones that stand out. And I reckon, the best is yet to come.

My abode lies near the college I frequent, a circumstance that I find to my liking. The streetscapes are predominantly apartments, yet there exists a handful of eateries and watering holes that are somewhat affordable and enjoyable. One such establishment has recently undergone a change of name, and whilst the prices have risen, the quality of service and libations is not entirely wanting. The populace is generally amiable, consisting mostly of students and those of modest means, drawn by the reasonable cost of lodging. Children are a common sight, with an elementary school situated within a short stroll from my residence. I count myself fortunate to know none of my neighbors, for they are given to the indulgence of cannabis and the management has seen fit to install an air freshener unit outside their door, a circumstance that my companion and I find both humorous and somewhat insulting. The structures that surround me are often venerable in appearance, though their interiors may have been renewed. A short distance away, newer apartment blocks have arisen, yet their construction leaves much to be desired, and their rents are disproportionately high, a state of affairs that is tolerated due to their proximity to the campus. A modest eatery nearby serves its wares on paper plates and prepares much of its fare in a microwave, though it is situated near a bus stop that facilitates easy access to the city center. A fueling station stands across the street, a place of dubious reputation, but the city's investment in the road's renovation has resulted in a pleasant sidewalk, verdant medians, and a more inviting atmosphere. My apartment complex is enveloped in a forest, with a few ancient trees having been felled, leaving behind stumps, yet the foliage remains dense. A tree line stretches behind the complex, and beyond lies another set of apartments. My address is 42nd Street, and just beyond lies 43rd, a street that is considerably less appealing. The sidewalks there are in a state of disrepair, and the buildings bear the marks of time. The trees that line the street serve as a camouflage for the dereliction that lies behind them. Crime is a presence on 43rd Street, with a particular concentration at an apartment complex there, though I am loath to cast blame entirely upon them. Across the street from my dwelling, another complex with a transient population and a history of criminal activity shares the blame. Yet, I find my surroundings to be tolerable, for I am able to afford the cost of living and there are ample amenities nearby. The university is within walking distance, and two bus stops provide easy access to the city and surrounding stores.

In the heart of the cul-de-sac, a colony of yellow-painted duplexes stand sentinel, their white porches and green metal roofs a stark contrast to the monotonous sea of modern homes. The houses are spaced haphazardly, as if nature herself had a say in their placement. A familiarity exists among the inhabitants, a kinship born of shared space and shared secrets. Evenings find us gathered at the end of the not-so-determined drive, conversation flowing like the creek that meanders through our neighborhood. Children laugh and play, their voices echoing through the fields that encircle us, while we adults reminisce about simpler times.

This godforsaken world of ours, so bereft of silence, is here, in this pocket of life, where time seems to stand still. The sun, that old bastard, casts its golden gaze upon the blue skies and white clouds that drift languidly overhead. The only intrusion is the distant wail of sirens, a ghostly reminder of the world beyond our haven. Last night, the peace was shattered by the howl of a tornado siren, a spectral voice from the storm. We huddled in the bathtub, our small dog trembling in my arms, my purse and pillows our makeshift fort. The big dog, that old cur, refused to join us, his barking a symphony of fear and confusion.

The storm passed, leaving behind a world transformed. The road steamed as the temperature plummeted, hailstones melting upon the hot asphalt. The sun emerged, and with it, a double rainbow, a promise of better days. I snapped a photograph, capturing the fleeting beauty, and shared it with those far away. The neighborhood awoke slowly, the symphony of life resuming its familiar tune. Dinner smelled like home, and the sound of children's laughter filled the air.

In this new land, I've found a haven, a sanctuary from the world's chaos. The streets are quiet, save for the distant bray of a donkey and the morning's rooster's clarion call. It's a small community, a village in the heart of the city, and I've been blessed to find my place among these simple folk.

In the halcyon days of my eighth-grade commencement, I found myself uprooted and deposited into this neighborhood. The initial dawn was as bleak as the first snowfall in a drought, forging friendships was a trial akin to traversing a barren wasteland. Yet, with time, the chill of solitude receded, and I found kinship two houses down, and another soul on my very street. The transient nature of youth took them away, but the echoes of their laughter and the ghosts of our games remain. The denizens who dwelt here when I first arrived still occupy these walls, like unyielding oaks weathering the seasons.

This is a neighborhood that can pass for the average American suburban expanse. Two-story houses stand sentinel along the streets, their silence only interrupted by the shrill cries of youth at play on weekends or balmy afternoons. Most days, the quiet is a tangible thing, a blanket that muffles the din of the world outside. Yet, it is a quiet that invites trust, for I have never been accosted by the darkness that so often lurks in the shadows of other places. My porch has never been a haven for thieves, my neighbors a sanctuary from the storm.

A park lies a stone's throw from my doorstep, a beacon of my youth. The echoes of my laughter still ring within its borders, a symphony of basketballs squeaking and footballs soaring through the air. My nose bears the scar of a Well, that's one way to get noticed, memory of a game that cost me a nose-full of dirt and a newfound respect for the game. Yet, the park remains a place of joy, where I now spend time with the innocents of my cousin's lineage, their laughter a reminder of my own youth. It is a place of nostalgia, of ghosts and memories that dance in the sunlight.

The neighborhood is a tapestry of diversity, woven with threads of various cultures. In the span of a mile, one can find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian eateries, a testament to the melting pot that is our world. Yet, the simplicity of a pizza shop is a constant, a beacon of comfort in the chaos of life. The stores are a veritable treasure trove, from the Indian-owned emporium that offers culinary delights to the Jewel-Osco that supplies the necessities of life. Yet, it is the Walgreens and the CVS that are the true heart of the neighborhood, their neon lights beacons in the night.

I am a man who has found solace in the rhythm of this place, a rhythm that is as steady and sure as the setting sun. For I have seen the darkness that lurks in the hearts of others, the horror stories that are whispered in the shadows of other neighborhoods. Yet, here, I am safe. Here, I am home.

The town I call home, Johnston, is a small, unassuming place, tucked away in the heart of South Carolina. It's a place where the land is as much a part of you as it is you are of it. The sun bears down on the fields, where cattle graze and peach trees stand sentinel, their fruit ripening in the blazing summer heat. The houses, scattered like islands in a vast sea of amber, are often two stories tall, their roofs gleaming in the sun, either metal or gray shingles keeping the blistering rays at bay. The road, if you can call it that, winds through the heart of the town, where the only stop light hangs like a sentinel, guarding the small stores that cater to the town's simple needs.

There's a Chinese restaurant, its sign flickering in the night, the scent of fried rice and lo mein wafting out. There's a Mexican restaurant, a burger joint, and a drugstore, its neon sign promising Cherry Coca-Cola, a taste of home. The grocery store is small, the aisles echoing with the sound of your own footsteps, the shelves filled with the necessities of life. There's a furniture store, its doors always open, inviting, the warm glow of the light spilling out onto the street. Attached to it is a pet groomers, the sound of clippers humming, a dog's wagging tail, a cat's contented purr. The school is small, its playground empty, the bell echoing through the quiet streets. The town is small, you could blink and miss it, but it's home, and it's enough.

The town is more than just a place to live, it's a way of life. It's the scent of freshly baked bread, the sound of children's laughter, the quiet hum of the town, a symphony of simple pleasures. It's the feel of the sun on your face, the taste of ripe peaches, the sound of the wind rustling through the leaves. It's the town that shaped me, the town that I'll always call home.

The first time I heard mention of this place, it was in the hushed whispers of a podcast, splayed across the shadows of my living room. The tale of a town where the price of a roof was more than a man's honest day's work. My eyes widened as I heard it, as the cost of each square foot was more than I could fathom. It was a secret, it seemed, one that none of my kin knew, and yet it was all around us, like a ghost in the machine. Prices so high they'd make a wheelbarrow weep, and yet we'd learned to dance in the rain of this life, to find the silver in the dross. The dusty scent of flea market trinkets clung to our hands like a lover's touch, and we'd laugh at the smell of adulthood, a scent as familiar as our own skin. Here, the thrifts were our temples, and we knelt before their altars, seeking solace in the faded clothes and musty books. In the heart of the city, where the streets were a river of steel and flesh, we found our quiet oasis, and within it, a community that cared not for idle chatter but for the echo of our own hearts. The piano next door played its own symphony, a melody that spoke of a quiet love, while the voices of the singers upstairs wept with joy and sorrow, each note a testament to our shared humanity. In this sprawling, impersonal expanse of steel and glass, we found our home, and in it, a sense of belonging that was as rare as a lighthouse in a storm. The city was alive, a beast that breathed and slept and dreamed, and we were but one of its myriad hearts.

The land in which I dwell is a sprawl of cookie-cutter homes, a testament to man's obsession with order and uniformity. The Homeowner's Association's vigilance is evident in every meticulously manicured yard, each a mirror reflection of its neighbors. Driveways are short, cars are two, and trees are small, their roots barely penetrating the earth. The streets are paved, smooth and unblemished, save for the occasional crack that speaks of age and neglect. Single story homes dominate, though the occasional two-story structure stands like a fortress amidst the sameness.

Mailboxes are not the solitary affairs they once were, but instead congregate in communal clusters at the end of each street, a testament to the HOA's desire for control. Retired folk, their faces weathered by time, make up the majority of the populace, though a scattering of the middle-aged and young professionals lend a touch of vitality to the place. The city, large in population but small in heart, offers amenities aplenty: a single mall, organic markets, and bargain outlets staffed by few. It is a place where one can find solace in familiarity, where the humdrum of daily life is punctuated by the occasional bark of a dog or the shuffle of a neighbor's footsteps. Yet, beneath the surface lies a quiet desperation, a longing for something more, something wild and untamed. But that is a story for another time.

Born in the faded heart of a Midwestern town, just beyond the shadow of a sprawling metropolis, I inhabit a humble neighborhood on the town's eastern flank. This quarter, the most impoverished, bears the scars of economic despair, where homes are rented or owned by those struggling to make ends meet. Yet, it carries a quiet dignity, with neighbors who offer a nod and a smile when you pass by. Crime does lurk here, its dark tendrils occasionally snaking through the streets, claiming lives and leaving families shattered. We've felt its chill, a son lost to a barroom's violence, and the occasional disappearance of our belongings. But our family has been spared the worst, our lives marked only by the echo of a distant gunshot.

Our town, like many, has been ravaged by the demon opioid. Fentanyl's grip has left countless lives forfeited, but there are those who fight back, offering resources against the tide. Rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions stand as beacons of hope amidst the despair.

In the face of adversity, our town possesses indomitable spirit. My son's elementary school, a sanctuary of learning and joy, tends to the smallest of hearts with tender care. The PTO's efforts bloom like flowers in the harshest soil, nurturing community and education. The school's staff, from the principal to the humblest janitor, are a testament to this spirit, ensuring no child goes hungry and no family is shamed by their circumstance. Yet, this spirit is not evenly distributed. The town's face-lift, while evident, is a farce, with the west side basking in the glow of improved roads and parks, while the east side fades into the background.

Still, our home, though it may not gleam like a palace, is a haven. It's a testament to the simple pleasures of a life well-lived. The trees outside our window whisper stories of our family's history, and the hum of the city is a reassuring lullaby. We've weathered the storms of life here, and we'll weather more. This is our home, our sanctuary, our town. We've been here for sixteen years, and we'll be here for many more.

My neighborhood is a wellspring of culture, a hilltop haven surrounded by edifices of yore. I dwell in a seven-story monolith across from the ancient live Theater, while a block away, the Hill harbors an arcade bar that draws diverse souls on balmy summer nights. Lines form, especially on weekends in June and July, as folks queue for admittance. A few blocks distant lies a park, expansive for its locale, ringed by concrete and stairs. In winter's grasp, the homeless erect their tents in orderly lines, seeking respite from the rain that drenches the city. Despite the infrequent snow, the cold permeates, and the homeless huddle close, within reach of the lone family center, where they can cleanse and warm themselves. My affinity for this city is not rooted in its historic facade or the architecture that sprawls across the hills descending to the sea. Instead, it is the people who captivate me. Hilltop, once a bastion of West Coast gang violence, bears the scars of its past, stories passed down through generations, whispering tales of federal raids and DEA sweeps. The people here labor hard, despite the notoriety of the neighborhood, striving to keep it clean and safe, their pride in their city unyielding. They warn that the Hill is no place for a white woman after dark, a remnant of old prejudices. Yet, I find solace here, in the streets that pulse with life, where jackets are offered more readily than threats, where a $5 can be bestowed with a simple, "You're beautiful and valuable." Here, I am alive, and the Hilltop is my home.

In the heart of Rural America lies a small town nestled in the embrace of Michigan's vast expanse, where the horizon stretches out like a canvas painted with rolling hills and farmlands. This is not a land of towering metropolises or bustling cities, but a place where the rhythm of life is dictated by the seasons and the whispering winds. No gleaming skyscrapers or neon lights here, just the quiet hum of small-town life. The nearest big-box store is a distant memory, and the only signs of civilization are the occasional tourist city that dots the landscape.

The town is surrounded by the embrace of two great lakes, Lake Michigan and Lake Charlevoix, their waters shimmering under the sun like a promise of tranquility. Everywhere one goes, one can find a stretch of sand to call their own, a place to dip one's feet into the cool, refreshing water. The homes here are a testament to the passage of time, each one a story waiting to be told. Some are newer, with their gleaming facades and modern amenities, while others bear the scars of age, their aluminum siding a relic of a bygone era. Each house is unique, a reflection of the hardworking soul that calls it home. Kids run up and down the streets, laughter echoing through the air like a symphony, while neighbors greet each other with a friendly nod or a warm smile.

The lawns are kept in order, a patchwork of green and brown, a stark contrast to the wild, untamed woods that surround the town. The scent of freshly cut grass mingles with the faint smell of charcoal from the grill, a testament to the simple pleasures of life. The houses here are not mere dwellings, but sanctuaries, a place to raise families and create memories. They are the heart of this community, the beating pulse that keeps it alive.

A walk down the street reveals the town's spirit. The county sheriff's department and jail sit nearby, a reminder of the law and order that keeps this town safe. Just beyond them lies the health department, a beacon of care and well-being. The recycling center, a proud testament to the town's commitment to the environment, sits just down the road. The baseball and softball fields nearby are a place of joy and camaraderie, the sound of laughter and cheers filling the air. The small airport, a testament to the town's spirit of adventure, is a place where dreams are takeoff and landing.

This is not a place of grandeur or opulence, but of simple, quiet beauty. It is a place where you can walk to the ice cream parlor, or bike to the park, where the rumbles of small planes are the soundtrack of your life. This is a place where you can walk into the town and feel instantly at home, because it is a place where people know each other, where you belong. It is a place of peace, of quiet contentment, a place where at the end of the day, you can truly feel safe and at home.

original_texts:
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
The first time I'd heard of my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was a little surprising. Almost every apartment in the area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. I'd never heard anything about that story and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know a few of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but we've learned how to be frugal over the years. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You smell a lot less in adulthood. You might start to smoke, or you might just be too accustomed to the state of things. But the flea market always asserts itself. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano. It wedges itself in the leather and stays in even after you wash it. Here, there're 3 thrift stores in walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can patronize two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it in the thrifts. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store is silent. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there's more and more of those. Cars and people flood it. It's a developing city, they say. Headquartering one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, it's still showing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everything and everyone is set on their own goals, and there isn't a whole lot anyone asks from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a little concerned means you care. You don't pry into anyone's life here, really. You can keep up your shell as long as you'd like, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors and they treat me pretty well. I try to make sure to clean after myself and leave them food and they do the same in kind. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I moved to this neighborhood just when I was about to start eighth grade. It was hard for me to make friends at first, but I ended up getting close to someone who lives two houses down from me and another guy that lives on my street. Neither of them lives there anymore but the memories are still there. The same people who lived here when I first moved here are still here for the most part. My neighborhood is pretty similar to your average American suburban neighborhood. The neighborhood has a lot of two-story houses in it. Every weekend or just whenever it is warm outside I hear the kids playing outside. The neighborhood is quiet most days of the week. I have never had a problem with any of the people in the neighborhood. You are left alone in this neighborhood unless you need help. I have ordered multiple packages online and have never gotten a package snatched off of my porch. I feel like I can trust my neighbors. There is a park a minute or two away from my house. I have a lot of memories there. I have played basketball, football, and baseball there with the other guys in the neighborhood before. I also ended up with one of my worst memories there when I got elbowed in the nose playing football, but the good memories outweigh the bad. Nowadays, whenever I go to that park it is to spend time with my cousin's kids. They are much younger than me and still like playing on swings and slides and all of that type of stuff. Just the thought of going to the park makes them excited. The park makes me very nostalgic for a number of different reasons now. The neighborhood is very diverse. You will find all kinds of food nearby. In just a one mile radius, you would be able to find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants. However, nowadays, a lot of people just use apps just as GrubHub and DoorDash to get their food delivered to them. The most popular food places are the fast food shops but you can get those near pretty much any suburban neighborhood. There are also plenty of pizza places. The stores here contain everything you would ever need. There are multiple dry cleaners nearby. There is a Walgreens and a CVS on the same street as well as a Jewel-Osco grocery store, which is popular in the Midwest. Some of the stores are even diverse as there is an Indian-owned store if you are ever in the mood to make some homemade Indian food or to buy some ready-made Indian food. Overall, I am a fan of my neighborhood. Reading on social media and seeing on the news some of the horror stories other people have to go through with their neighbors makes me grateful for mine.
My neighborhood is nearby to the college that I attend, and for that I quite enjoy living there. There are mostly apartment buildings, but a few restaurants and bars that are fun to go to and aren't terribly expensive to go to. One of the bars was just renamed, and that one is more expensive to go to but it isn't really the worst quality of service or drinks there. Most of the people are nice. They are either college kids or they are lower income, since the apartment housing isn't very expensive. There's a lot of children nearby since there is an elementary school within walking distance of my apartment. I don’t know my neighbors, but I don’t really want to. They smoke a lot of weed and so the management of my building put an air freshener unit right across from their door, which my boyfriend and I found very funny. It’s almost insulting. The buildings that are around me are usually pretty old looking but might have renovated interiors. Down the street a bit there are brand new apartments, but I don’t like them because I know the construction done on them wasn’t particularly good. They’re cheaply built but the rent is expensive, which I think is such a scam but because they’re near campus, the management of those buildings can get away with it. There is a really cheap restaurant about five minutes from where I live that serves food only on paper plates and most of what they make is microwaved. Then across from that is a gas station, which I’ve heard isn’t a very good place to work. But thanks to some money from the city, the road was redone last summer so that there’s a nice big sidewalk, lots of grass on the medians and sides of the roads, and now the area is a little nicer. But the apartment building I live in is shrouded in tress. They cut a few of them down, so there are a few stumps, but there are a lot more trees where I live than down the road. Behind my apartment complex is a tree line and then another set of apartments. I live on 42nd street, but right behind is 43rd street and that one isn’t as nice. The sidewalks are really bad and falling apart, and most of the buildings on it look shabby. There are a lot of trees on this street, but that is probably to hide what the buildings look like.
